definitions.definition: To cause (something) to move rapidly in opposite directions alternatingly.
examples: He shook the can of soda for thirty seconds before delivering it to me, so that, when I popped it open, soda went everywhere.

definitions.definition: To move (one's head) from side to side, especially to indicate refusal , reluctance , or disapproval .
examples: Shaking his head, he kept repeating “No, no, no”.

definitions.definition: To move or remove by agitating; to throw off by a jolting or vibrating motion.
examples: to shake fruit down from a tree
Her father’s death shook her terribly.
He was shaken by what had happened.

definitions.definition: To lose , evade , or get rid of (something).
examples: I can’t shake the feeling that I forgot something.

definitions.definition: To move from side to side.

examples: She was shaking it on the dance floor.

definitions.definition: To give a tremulous tone to; to trill.
examples: to shake a note in music
The experience shook my religious belief.

definitions.definition: To be agitated; to lose firmness.

main_definition: ( transitive , ergative ) To cause (something) to move rapidly in opposite directions alternatingly.
secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To move (one's head) from side to side, especially to indicate refusal , reluctance , or disapproval .
( transitive ) To move or remove by agitating; to throw off by a jolting or vibrating motion.
( transitive ) To disturb emotionally; to shock .
( transitive , idiomatic ) To lose , evade , or get rid of (something).
( intransitive ) To move from side to side.
( intransitive , usually as "shake on" ) To shake hands .
( transitive ) To give a tremulous tone to; to trill.
( transitive , figurative ) To threaten to overthrow.
( intransitive , figurative ) To be agitated; to lose firmness.
